text: Bottle at home. Pours reddish brown, nose is malty, dark fruit, taste is caramel, toffee, biscuit.

12th June 2014Tasting at Bruces pad. Thanks to Scopinho. Almost opaque dark brown beer, small pale tan head. Light airy palate, fine carbonation. Airy dark malts. Tangy marmite come umami. Touch of dark fruits. Airy finish. Nice enough.

Bottle split at Bruces Pad, thanks to Paul S Copey purveyor of genuine Scottish Shilling beers, 12/06/14.
Lightish shade of black with a good sized tan covering that retains well.
Nose carries light shades of plastic, dark malts, cocoa pangs, earthy, dark toffee, dark fruit rinse.
Taste comprises dark fruit, liquorice, earthy, dark malt, light roast, cocoa powder, leather, toffee fudge.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light roasty tones in the close.
Ok stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from Cornelius. Gusher. Dark red big creamy head. Malt and pudding nose. Complex sweet toffee but bitter underlying tones. A little fizzy but otherwise very tasty.

Bottle at home. Slow gusher! It pours cloudy deep brown with a thick beige head. The nose is wood, earth, toast, cocoa, meatiness, candy, must and some spice. The taste is toasty, earth, nice bitterness, meaty, caramel, old wood, chocolate, liquorice, leather, coffee, tobacco, warming alcohol, cola and dark fruit with a dry, somewhat spicy finish. Medium+ body, moderate carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Interesting, good depth and balance. Another well executed beer from Luckie Ales. Im really enjoying what they do.

AROMA: hay, nuts, toast, dough, 
APPEARANCE: amber, red, hazy, white foam, rocky head, 
TASTE: very bitter, medium sourness, 
PALATE: full body, thick feel, average carbonation, astringent, bitter, long finish, 
OVERALL: very good ale, aromas mostly malty and a bit of yeast, interesting balance of intense sourness vs intense bitterness; lingering bitterness and toast.

50cl bottle thanks to Anthony. This is an ale that definitely is in the Scottish tradition. The extra level of alcohol has brought out a rich raisin aroma and taste and there is just enough freshness on the finish to make you want more - shame I ended up sharing this one.

Bottle shared at home. Pours dark red-brown with a thick creamy head. Big malt and raisin aromas, luscious. Nuts and biscuit also. Caramel and toffee. Lovely subtle balancing bitterness to all that malt-sweet. A stunning beer.
500ml bottle from Cornelius, Edinburgh - clear dark reddish brown, thin beige head, sweet malty aroma, toffee caramel, sweet, fruity, moderate carbonation, hard to tell this one is 7% abv
500ml bottle from AleseLA. Dark chestnut brown, reasonable head. Fruity chocolate malt aroma. Sweet fruity liquorice malt flavour. Sharp with sweet aftertaste. Not a bad beer.
500ml Bottle - Dark brown with a foamy head. Fruity, nutty and malty aroma with notrs of dried fruit and marzipan. The taste is very fruity with fruitcake, raisins and caramel detected.

bottle at home from alesela
 pours clear deep ruby-garnet with a light off-white crema of a head, giving off a nose redolent of an autumn trek through a forest, with red berries, damp soil and crunchy leaves. The body is fairly full, yet light, with gentle carbonation. Its fairly rich, with a big booze hit up front, slightly astringent burnt toast malt and plenty of dried fruit sweetness afterwards in a long fruity finish.

Bottle from BeerHive, Edinburgh [220213]
Deep chestnut brown, clear, frothy slightly off white head, good colour
Aroma of rich caramel malts, quite rich soft toffee, touch of doughy malt, soft dark fruits, some raisin, mainly rich malts
Taste of smooth malts, rich dark caramel, rich toffee, soft raisin, dough, alcohol very well hidden
Palate - soft to medium carb, medium body, smooth texture. Finish as main flavour, smooth rich caramel, light roast
Overall - Another well made beer from Luckie Ales

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Drunk via cask at the Hanging Bat December 21st.

Another palate pleaser with a mouthfeel and taste like no other. Exactly what Rich has said below. Except it seems I liked it more. WIthout a doubt the best Scottish Old Ale brewed at any time in living memory.

Bottle on 02/02/14.
Wonderfully alive deep with great depth of flavour & complexity.  Lovely restrained smoky quality.  Could be confused as a collaborative beer with Schlenkerla. Mmmm. Unassuming, great value and puts most £10 and above craft bottles to shame.

[cask at the Hanging Bat, Edinburgh] Dark mahogany reddish-brown, thick tan head. Sweet caramel and chocolate aroma, touch of booze. Tastes sweet, rich and warming - molasses, prunes, raisins, caramel, before finishing warm and with a touch of alcohol on the finish. A classic old ale, I love beers like this [20122012]

Bottle. Slow gusher.  Dark ruby red brown with thick solid tan head. Heavy malty aroma, chocolate, slightly spiced caramel and toffee. Taste is slightly chocolatey, toffee, biscuit, nutty with a slight fruitiness. Quite sweet. Its alright, not very exciting.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2014 Bottle from Cornelius. Dark brown body with red tints. Large off-white head that leaves light lacing. Strong aroma of yeast, dark chocolate, orange and rum. Flavour of sweet toffee, sugar, rum and raisin. Spicy finish. Tastes quite boozy for 7.0% ABV. Medium body with an oily mouthfeel. Lively fizz. An excellent beer - lovely warming alcohol and rich, heavy flavours.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2012 cask at hanging bat ... brown ... thin tan head ...light bitter blackcurrant nose sort sweet tolffee roast ... chewy dark malts ... litle alcohol... lght woody chocolate linger

 Bottle at home ... cause the cap popped damn and blast ... brown ... thin lacing ... sweet toffee ... brown suger nose ... rich chedy malts ... sweet roast ... soft toffee ... 3.6
